review.body:
When I found this book my first thought was “Tattoos and threesomes, what can go wrong”
Oh so much.

This was one of the most boring read I have ever forced myself through, and I only did that because it was too late to get my money back.

It’s impossible to get a read of the characters because they a...
3 1/2 stars. I like the way Iles writes and enjoy the characters. I have been reading the Penn Cage books out of order but I still enjoy the writing, the characters and the settings.

book.title: The Paper Magician (The Paper Magician Trilogy, #1)

review.body: Fun book at the beginning and end, but I didn't like what happens in the middle. It was weird. Also, the end just seems to come together really quickly. I bought the books as a package, so I'll read the second and third.

Maggie and her family are delighted to have a full house at their bed and breakfast as summer is coming to an end. However, the elderly couple is a real pain, so no one is too upset when they both die within minutes of each other. The sheriff is sure that one of them was murdered, and since he ha...
The story is heart rending but what a wonderful ache!
Probably the only book in the series that is actually good. I'm happy I stuck around with the series, because this one was a treat. The other nine... Not so much. Now on to the 11th!

Sierra Collins
12/16/15
Book Review
Paper Towns by John Green

Paper Towns is a young-adult fiction and mystery. This book is about seventeen year old Quentin Jacobsen figuring out what his future holds with lifelong friend Margo. They both go to high school together, but it’s not your typical love hi...
Cleverly written and great illustrations. Both my kids and I enjoyed this story.

By the time you finish Canned and Crushed, a middle-grade novel, the main character and the manic style will have won you over. Because finding a novel with a Hispanic protagonist had proved difficult during her teaching days, Belford drew on her experiences with children of migrant workers and w...

book.title: The Dark at the End of the Tunnel

review.body: Well written and consistently solid, there’s not one story in The Dark at the End of the Tunnel that I wanted to skip over, even the one or two I had read previously in their original releases. It’s not only a delight to reread these stories, it’s great to see how they fit together as part of thi...
very disappointing, I was sorry not to be able to read it. His essay in NY Times was so much better.
i know i read this...i just don't know where my review went...will add it when i find it.
I'd describe this as a more realistic/ relatable version of a Nicholas Sparks story. I read this in a three and a half hour sitting as I couldn't put it down.

Review posted at Shiro Reads

What I liked:

Hayashi, who is straight, struggled quite a lot, and seeing his internal struggle, confusion and conflicted mind reflected in the pages as he slowly notices every little cute thing about Shinohara is one of the sweetest parts of the story. He went to such...

I do not often read steampunk but do read a lot of paranormal romance. This one was a bit of both and I absolutely loved it. The characters are well-drawn and the story line sucked me in and pulled me along until the very last word.

Miles and Lucy make a great couple. Miles is brooding and solita...
Awesome book... Great storyline, sex scenes and twists!!!

3/16/16
Book Review
Sierra Collins

Meaningful Curriculum for Young Children by Eva Moravcik

Before I begin, this book is nonfiction. I learned multiple things in this book about children and how to handle and deal with different things. I learned that there are all different type of characteristics...

book.title: Battle Bunny
book.publisher: Simon & Schuster Books for Young Readers

review.body: This is a fantastic, clever, and very complex book! Not to read, but the depths are deep. It's actually two stories after the birthday bunny scribbles out parts and transforms himself and the story into Battle Bunny! Love it!

The strange, compelling, and very dense nature of Desai's relentless writing is curious. The writing is not labored; its lush. There's not an extraneous word, though there are lots of words. Each sentence propels a thousand thoughts; each thought an image; each image a vision of tradition, aliena...

book.title: A Dance with Dragons: Dreams and Dust (A Song of Ice and Fire #5, Part 1 of 2)

review.body: All of my favourite characters' narratives are back so I much preferred this to A Feast for Crows. I don't feel like anything has really been resolved in this one so I'm hoping part 2 will do that. Absolutely desperate to see where a few of the individual storylines go now!
